page.title: 12BUILDING STYLES IN NE LEICS
page.content: Most buildings in the area are private houses or farm buildings constructed of red brick or marlstone rock, a sandy coloured stone used abundantly in the Rutland area. Some cottages are rendered and painted white while others retain their brick or stone appearance. The row of cottages by the old Lowesby station originally built for railway employees are still occupied as private houses. Most housing in the area is owner occupied as is Lowesby Hall, a fine mansion whose records date back to 1313.It is set in nine acres of ornamental gardens laid out by Sir Edwin Lutyens. Lowesby church is even earlier, it and Lowesby village being erected to serve the hall. The ruins of an earlier village may be seen in a nearby field, evident by the mounds and bumps which can be seen there.
